authors.name: Stephen Douglas Russell
authors.affiliation: Mycota Lab / The Hoosier Mushroom Society

description: {"blocks":[{"key":"cq64a","text":"'This protocol is best used when preparing macrofungal specimens for Sanger sequencing or as a secondary extraction protocol for ONT nanopore barcoding. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a2u60","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fjdl2","text":"The quality of a DNA extraction method is a primary limiting factor in the total number of samples that will return a result with nanopore barcoding of fungi. The \"quick\" extraction protocol will often yield a positive result for 80-85% of general fungal collections (less if biased with polypores and recalcitrant species). Utilizing this extraction protocol pushes that number to nearly 100%. It is more time consuming and utilizes more expensive chemicals, but may be worth considering for important specimens that fail with the quick extraction protocol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"fvt5u","text":"Add 600uL of   to 1.5mL eppi tubes containing your tissue.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":13,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fs8pc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"reagents","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":0,"cas_number":"","guid":"412F866C341F11EE9D4302C0B41BC903","linfor":"","mol_weight":0,"name":"Nuclei Lysis Solution, 1000ml","pubchem_id":"0","public":0,"rrid":"","sku":"A7943","stats":{"total_protocols":0},"url":"","vendor":{"affiliation":null,"affiliations":[],"badges":[],"blocked_by_you":false,"blocked_you":false,"hide_following":false,"id":23,"image":{"placeholder":"https://www.protocols.io/img/vendors/placeholder.png","source":"https://www.protocols.io/img/vendors/placeholder.png"},"is_verified_user":false,"link":"http://www.promega.com","name":"Promega","note":null,"research_interests":null,"username":null,"verified":0}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"agnnb","text":"Place tissue from your specimens into each tube using tweezers. Utilize a piece about the size of a grain of rice or smaller. It should easily drop to the bottom of the tube. The tissue can be either fresh or dried. Label the tube with the appropriate number. Wipe the tweezers off with a Kimwipe or paper towel in between each specimen. These tubes can be stored at room temperature until they are ready to be used. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"65c9n","text":"Grind the tissue well in each tube using a sterile pestle.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"at768","text":"Heat the tubes at   for at least  . It is fine to leave it in longer.
